is transfer that onto some kind of

this is a fancy culinary term for
pricking the dough with a fork and I
guess if you wanted to you could use two
hands and two forks and theoretically
finish in half the time but I get paid
by the hour so I'm a no hurry in case

going to prevent the puff pastry from
rising too much okay normally we want
this stuff to puff up nice and high but
here what we're going for is nice thin
crisp layers so we'll go ahead and dock
that all over and once our dough has
been docked it's ready to be dusted with
some good old-fashioned granulated white
sugar not too too much but we do want to
lightly dust that over the entire
surface at which point this is ready to
cover with several things the first of
which would be some parchment paper that
we will place over the top followed by
three or four layers of foil that I
folded up and then last but not least we
will press everything down with another
sheet pan and by the way the foil is
only there so the top sheet pan comes in
a little bit of contact with the pastry
so depending on the pans you're using
that may or may not be necessary and I
will touch on that in the blog post but
anyway once that set we can go ahead and
transfer that into the center of a 400

point we'll pull it out but don't get
excited it's not done all we're going to
do is remove the paper and the foil
and the top pan but not necessarily in
that order
and hopefully thanks to that pressing
and the docking we're going to have some

what we're going to do is simply pop
that back in the oven
